title: Effect of Enzyme Inhibition on a Parasite

content.description:
Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

Cryptosporidium parvum (C. parvum) is a single-celled, eukaryotic parasite that infects human cells in the digestive system and causes illness.

Although it is a eukaryote, C. parvum does not have functional mitochondria and generates <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> only through glycolysis. C. parvum uses the enzyme lactate dehydrogenase to perform fermentation after glycolysis.

Two chemicals, gossypol and <math alttext="F X 11" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>FX</mtext> <mn>11</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, are noncompetitive inhibitors of lactate dehydrogenase. Researchers investigated the effectiveness of gossypol and <math alttext="F X 11" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FX11</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> as drugs to kill C. parvum. In the experiment, human cells were treated with different concentrations of either gossypol or <math alttext="F X 11" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FX</mtext><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> after infection with C. parvum, and the relative growth of C. parvum compared with that of control cells was measured (Figures 1 and 2).

content.question: (a) Describe how C. parvum obtains the glucose it needs for glycolysis after it has infected another cell. Explain the role of lactate dehydrogenase in enabling C. parvum to continue producing <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>ATP</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> by glycolysis.

Explain the role of lactate dehydrogenase in enabling C. parvum to continue producing <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>ATP</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> by glycolysis.

(b) Identify the independent variable used in the experiment. Identify the difference between the control cells and the experimental cells used in the experiment. Justify the researchers using a different range of concentrations for <math alttext="F X 11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FX11</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> than was used for gossypol.

(c) Based on the data in Figure 1, identify the concentration of gossypol that reduced C. parvum growth to <math alttext="50%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of that in control cells.

(d) Researchers discovered a strain of C. parvum that expresses a functional variation of the lactate dehydrogenase gene. A <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sequence comparison showed that the variant differs from the normal sequence in the region that codes for the enzymeâ€™s allosteric site. Predict the effect of <math alttext="F X 11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FX11</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> treatment on C. parvum cells that express this variant of lactase dehydrogenase. Provide reasoning to support your prediction. Explain how gossypol and <math alttext="F X 11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FX11</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> might be used as drugs to treat C. parvum infections in humans without negatively affecting human cells.
